Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 14. The Circumstances of his Renunciation
On another occasion the Bodhisattva said to his charioteer, “Charioteer, prepare my best horse, quickly! We shall go to the gardens." "As you command," he said, and made preparations as ordered.
Manual - English: In whatever places are approproate, from the four gates of the palace, depict general scenes of old age, illness, death, and renunciation.

Sun of Faith - English: When the time came they boarded the chairot and set off. Along the road the Bodhisattva saw a decrepit old man walking with the help of a cane. ***At the hour agreed upon, they climbed into the carriage and went off. On their way, the young people met a bent old man who was hobbling along with the help of a cane.
"What is this?" he asked the charioteer.
"Divine One," the chairioteer replied, "This is an old person. He will die before long."
"Yet am I not free from the reality of aging?"
"Even divine ones are not free from the reality of growing old."
"Turn the chariott around!" the Bodhisattva ordered. "Return to the palace!"
When they returned the palace, the Bodhisattva despaired, "See how I am not free from aging."
Then, when King Shudodhana asked the charioteer, "Did the Youth enjoy the pleasure garden?" he told the king what happened in detail.

"Is this not the words of the soothsayers coming true?" worried the King. "Will he renounce the world? We will give him all pleasures of the senses, and he shall not renounce the world." So the King provided the Bodhisattva with every pleasure of the senses.
Inscription - English: The bodhisattva's mind is troubled as the consorts play.

Sun of Faith - English: Then as before, the Bodhisattva boarded his chariot and set out for the pleasure garden.
He saw a sick man aflicted by disease, swollen and wasted away.
The Bodhisattva asked, "What is this?"
“Divine One,” the charioteer replied, "This is a sick person."
"Am I not free from the reality of sickness?"
"Even divine ones are not free from the reality of illness."
Again, they returned to the palace. "See how even I am not free from sickness!" thought the Bodhisattva.
As before, the king provided the bodhisattva with all the pleasures of the senses.
Inscription - English: The bodhisattva's mind is troubled as the consorts play.

Sun of Faith - English: Again the Bodhisattva boarded the charriot and set out for the pleasure garden. He saw a corpse carried on a stretcher and wrapped in a shroud. A torch bearer and a large group of people walked in front, while the mourners followed behind.
Inscription - English: The young prince sees death. Death

Sun of Faith - English: The Bodhasattva asked, “What is this?”
“Divine One," the charioteer replied, "This is a dead person.”
“Am I not free from the reality of death?”
"Even divine ones are not free from the reality of passing away."
Again they returned to the palace.
"See how I am not free from the reality of death," thought the Bodhisattva.
As before, the king provided the bodhisattva with all the pleasures of the senses.

The gods of the Pure Abodes thought, "The Bodhisattva certainly has the cause, which is the strength of previous effort. Although he has the cause, which is the strength of his previous effort, he must rely on immediate circumstances. Therefore we should encourage him to renounce the world.
So they emanated a renunciant with shaved head and saffron robes going from house to house begging for alms.
Again, the Bodhisattva boarded the charriot and set out for the pleasure garden. He saw the renunciant with shaved head, wearing saffron robes, and holding a bowl in his hand as he walked along.
The Bodhisattva asked, "What is this?"
"Divine One, this is a renunciant. He is well disciplined and more."
"Turn the chairiot around and go back to him!"
The chaioteer did as he was commanded, turning back toward him. The Bodhisattva questioned the renunciant, who explained at length how to renounce the world.
"Excellent!" said the Bodhisattva, and returned to the palace.
"Wonderful! I shall renounce the world, and go from home to homelessness!" thought the Bodhisattva. And he reflected with joy on this great ambition.
